trans-unit.source: Material slots
trans-unit.target: Material slots

trans-unit.source: Intermediate Artist Programmer
trans-unit.target: Intermediate Artist Programmer

trans-unit.source: Models can use multiple materials. You can set the materials in the model's material slots.
trans-unit.target: Models can use multiple materials. You can set the materials in the model's material slots.

trans-unit.source: Material slots
trans-unit.target: Material slots

trans-unit.source: For example, the second material slot in this model specifies the material for the visor and the shoulder and chest plate stripes. By changing the material in this slot, we change the material used in these parts of the model.
trans-unit.target: For example, the second material slot in this model specifies the material for the visor and the shoulder and chest plate stripes. By changing the material in this slot, we change the material used in these parts of the model.

trans-unit.source: Materials
trans-unit.target: Materials

trans-unit.source: The material slots themselves — their number and position — are defined in the model source file (eg .fbx, .obj, etc). You can't edit material slots in Game Studio; you can only change which materials are used in each slot.
trans-unit.target: The material slots themselves — their number and position — are defined in the model source file (eg .fbx, .obj, etc). You can't edit material slots in Game Studio; you can only change which materials are used in each slot.

trans-unit.source: Set materials on a model
trans-unit.target: Set materials on a model

trans-unit.source: You can change the materials a model uses in two places:
trans-unit.target: You can change the materials a model uses in two places:

trans-unit.source: Under the Materials properties of the model itself:
trans-unit.target: Under the Materials properties of the model itself:

trans-unit.source: Model materials
trans-unit.target: Model materials

trans-unit.source: !Note This affects every instance of this model.
trans-unit.target: !Note This affects every instance of this model.

trans-unit.source: In the model component of an entity or prefab:
trans-unit.target: In the model component of an entity or prefab:

trans-unit.source: Model materials on entity
trans-unit.target: Model materials on entity

trans-unit.source: This only affects this instance or prefab.
trans-unit.target: This only affects this instance or prefab.

trans-unit.source: Meshes and material slots
trans-unit.target: Meshes and material slots

trans-unit.source: Models imported from modeling software can contain meshes. Meshes can share materials via material slots.
trans-unit.target: Models imported from modeling software can contain meshes. Meshes can share materials via material slots.

trans-unit.source: Mesh
trans-unit.target: Mesh

trans-unit.source: The association between a mesh and a material slot is defined in the model source file. You can't change these associations in Game Studio, but you can change them in code at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The association between a mesh and a material slot is defined in the model source file. You can't change these associations in Game Studio, but you can change them in code at runtime.

trans-unit.source: To change the association between a mesh and a material, use:
trans-unit.target: To change the association between a mesh and a material, use:

trans-unit.source: MyModelComponent.Model.Meshes[submeshIndex].MaterialIndex = materialIndex;
trans-unit.target: MyModelComponent.Model.Meshes[submeshIndex].MaterialIndex = materialIndex;

trans-unit.source: To change or add a material to the list of materials:
trans-unit.target: To change or add a material to the list of materials:

trans-unit.source: MyModelComponent.Materials[ExistingOrNewMaterialIndex] = myMaterial;
trans-unit.target: MyModelComponent.Materials[ExistingOrNewMaterialIndex] = myMaterial;

trans-unit.source: Merging meshes
trans-unit.target: Merging meshes

trans-unit.source: When Stride draws a model with meshes, it performs one GPU draw call for each mesh. By default, to improve performance, at build time, Stride merges meshes that share materials.
trans-unit.target: When Stride draws a model with meshes, it performs one GPU draw call for each mesh. By default, to improve performance, at build time, Stride merges meshes that share materials.

trans-unit.source: Mesh
trans-unit.target: Mesh

trans-unit.source: In the example above, there are five meshes and five draw calls. After merging, there are three meshes and three draw calls.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, there are five meshes and five draw calls. After merging, there are three meshes and three draw calls.

trans-unit.source: !Note When Stride merges meshes, it merges the vertex and index buffers. This means you can't draw the meshes separately at runtime, and you can't change the original mesh position (transformation matrix). The meshes become a single mesh with a single material and a single transformation matrix (relative to the model).
trans-unit.target: !Note When Stride merges meshes, it merges the vertex and index buffers. This means you can't draw the meshes separately at runtime, and you can't change the original mesh position (transformation matrix). The meshes become a single mesh with a single material and a single transformation matrix (relative to the model).

trans-unit.source: !Note When Stride merges meshes, it changes the draw order of elements. In the case of transparent materials, this can produce different results.
trans-unit.target: !Note When Stride merges meshes, it changes the draw order of elements. In the case of transparent materials, this can produce different results.

trans-unit.source: !Note When you create a physics collider from a model, Stride builds separate convex hulls for each mesh in the model. If the meshes are merged, only one mesh remains per material, so convex hulls are also built from merged meshes.
trans-unit.target: !Note When you create a physics collider from a model, Stride builds separate convex hulls for each mesh in the model. If the meshes are merged, only one mesh remains per material, so convex hulls are also built from merged meshes.

trans-unit.source: Disable mesh merging
trans-unit.target: Disable mesh merging

trans-unit.source: You might want to disable mesh merging if you want to:
trans-unit.target: You might want to disable mesh merging if you want to:

trans-unit.source: animate a mesh
trans-unit.target: animate a mesh

trans-unit.source: change the material of a mesh at runtime
trans-unit.target: change the material of a mesh at runtime

trans-unit.source: To disable mesh merging on a model:
trans-unit.target: To disable mesh merging on a model:

trans-unit.source: Select the model you want to disable mesh merging for.
trans-unit.target: Select the model you want to disable mesh merging for.

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid, disable Merge meshes.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid, disable Merge meshes.

trans-unit.source: Disable merge meshes
trans-unit.target: Disable merge meshes

trans-unit.source: Disable merging for specific meshes
trans-unit.target: Disable merging for specific meshes

trans-unit.source: To disable merging only for specific meshes, enable their corresponding nodes.
trans-unit.target: To disable merging only for specific meshes, enable their corresponding nodes.

trans-unit.source: Select the model that contains the meshes.
trans-unit.target: Select the model that contains the meshes.

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid, under Skeleton, make sure the model has a skeleton associated with it.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid, under Skeleton, make sure the model has a skeleton associated with it.

trans-unit.source: Model skeleton
trans-unit.target: Model skeleton

trans-unit.source: For more information about skeletons, see Animation.
trans-unit.target: For more information about skeletons, see Animation.

trans-unit.source: In the Asset View, select the skeleton.
trans-unit.target: In the Asset View, select the skeleton.

trans-unit.source: Select model skeleton
trans-unit.target: Select model skeleton

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid, under Nodes, select the nodes that correspond to the meshes you don't want to merge.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid, under Nodes, select the nodes that correspond to the meshes you don't want to merge.

trans-unit.source: Nodes
trans-unit.target: Nodes

trans-unit.source: !Tip To see which nodes correspond to which mesh, open the model source file in a modeling application such as Maya.
trans-unit.target: !Tip To see which nodes correspond to which mesh, open the model source file in a modeling application such as Maya.

trans-unit.source: !Note Make sure you don't disable nodes that are animated at runtime.
trans-unit.target: !Note Make sure you don't disable nodes that are animated at runtime.

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also
